headline: Easy Roasted Cabbage
description: To get sweet nuttiness from caramelization and browning, you'll want to cut cabbage up into fat wedges and roast at high heat, for a deeply browned exterior and tender, meaty interior.

video.description: Cutting the cabbage up into fat wedges and roasting at high heat creates a nice contrast between deeply browned exterior and tender, meaty interior. [Video: Serious Eats Video. Technique: J. Kenji L처pez-Alt]
video.name: How to Roast Cabbage

name: Easy Roasted Cabbage
keywords: cabbage, fall, low carb, side, vegetable, winter
recipeIngredient: 1 medium head cabbage, cut into 6 to 8 wedges
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 500째F (260째C). Line a rimmed baking sheet with aluminum foil.

Arrange cabbage wedges on baking sheet in a single layer. Drizzle with olive oil on one side, then season with salt and pepper. Flip wedges, drizzle other side with oil, and season with salt and pepper.
Place baking sheet in oven and roast until lightly browned, about 10 minutes. Flip wedges and continue roasting until tender and deeply browned, another 10 minutes, then serve.

review.reviewBody: I saw a similar idea on a Netflix cooking that involved high-temp grilling. After grilling, the cabbage was layered with a pickle of some type, then dressed with a nutty salsa. I gave it my best shot and served it one. My wife raised an eyebrow, then tasted it and said "do that again."

What's the purpose of lining the baking sheet with foil? Just easier cleanup? It seems wasteful to take a perfectly good aluminum sheet and line it with aluminum foil just so you can later throw out the foil and save 2 minutes washing the baking sheet. Or, am I missing something here...?

I do see why one would line the baking sheet with parchment when making cookies or something, since they cook differently and it helps them release, but I roast veggies and other food all the time on a baking sheet with no problems.
These recent recipes for roasting brassicas have called for a 500 degree oven. Would 550 be even better if your oven can go that high?

Also works with purple cabbage. Did it without foil and in thick (2 inch) slices and it was fine. It's not the easiest thing to eat - slippery and deconstructs itself as soon as you put fork and knife to it. It might be even nicer if the wedges are smaller, maybe 1/2 inch thick overall and put into a warm salad with chewy grain and dried fruit - cranberries or currants?

My plan is to do this tonight, or maybe tomorrow? My question is: what next? How do you serve these? Right out of the oven, or cooled and as part of a salad? Is there a sauce that would work well, for instance?
